channel.title: Parents moving to australia
channel.description: so yeah, my parents are moving to canberra, im not really gonna be moving out there with them im staying in london but i'll have to go and live out there during summer (which i guess is winter out there) so whats canberra like? and whats australian winter like?

ya so update, parents accepted offer on the house today apparently, so thats like the big obsticle out of the way

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Taxation is the same here, with tax brackets and a certain amount of non-taxable income.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

We pay 6% VAT on basic needs such as bread etc and 19% for everything else.

Our income is progressively taxed: the first €18.218 is taxed with 33,45% The part between €18.218 and €32.738 41,95% and so on. Every Euro above €54.367 is taxed with 52%.

So someone who earns €19.000,- has to pay €6421,97 tax (€6093,92 + €328,05). Tax exemption: €1772, so €4649,97. If you have a house, and have a mortgage, the interest you have to pay over that mortgage is deducable too. So in the end, you don’t pay that much.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

You are exactly along my thought line.

Theres nothing wrong with social support, but its too easy to cheat the system just because you screwed up your life early on and didn’t take advantage of any opportunities to fix it.

They smoke and drink all through highschool and drop out, and then in 5 years they blame the leader of the country or economics.

agreed to your second part, I also think disabled should be redefined.

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:34, topic:387365”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=483168.msg3541922#msg3541922 date=1300923834]

SPREADING THE WEALTH RADEON
[/quote]Socialism. Is it not?

Def is. I didn’t know you followed the same viewpoint as me with entitlement programs and government handouts[/quote]

Well I’m not all out against social support. I just don’t think people who fail at life because they chose not to work as hard as the rest or because they were distracted by drugs should receive our hard earned money.

Students, the elderly, newly married couples, the disabled and orphans should be the recipients of social support.

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:35, topic:387365”]Welfare isn’t the problem Frell. It has its place. It’s the sense of entitlement to welfare that’s the problem.

The other problem is the job market itself. Even low skilled dead end jobs have so much red tape and bureaucratic bullshit surrounding them that it’s ridiculous.
For example, if you want to work for a council[/quote]

got to this bit and said no shit, working for any council no matter how much of a dead end job is going to have red tape man

Radeon:

Taxation here is terrible. If you have a semi-decent job which contributes to society, 40% of your money goes to the government. Whilst if your are a jobless waste of space and contribute nothing to society, you don’t pay any tax and the government gives you pocket money to spend on drugs.

im a useless jobless waste of space who contributes nothing to society who doesn’t get taxed, but I don’t get “government handouts” !!

brb australia

EDIT: I can actually apply for jobseekers allowance but I’d actually have to look for a job and there are ways around it but fuck that shit

Moparisthebest:

Is that like sales tax? That is ridiculous! Here I pay 6.5% sales tax, and I think it is too much.

somewhat, vat only applies to luxury items such as chocolate, fizzy drinks and alcohol, perfumes and computer hardware etc but we don’t pay it on “necessary” items such as groceries

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Welfare isn’t the problem Frell. It has its place. It’s the sense of entitlement to welfare that’s the problem.

The other problem is the job market itself. Even low skilled dead end jobs have so much red tape and bureaucratic bullshit surrounding them that it’s ridiculous.
For example, if you want to work for a council here and simply direct traffic (ie, the guy that holds the stop/slow sign and turns it around every so often), you need to do something like a month or more of occupational health and safety.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I wouldn’t know about that Radeon. Some of the highest earning people do find ways to avoid tax, and legally too; I don’t know about a figure as low as $25, but I know that some rich people pay less in tax than blue collar workers.

Usually I would be for socialism, but I had a bit of a change of heart recently after reading http://www.paulgraham.com/wealth.html
It was quite an eye opener for me, and I’m sure somebody here will find it an interesting read. It basically elaborates on things such as the pie fallacy, and that wealth is created (and not fixed, hard limits such as timber, metals, etc aside).
I’d never really thought of it before, because I had never really considered that money and wealth were intrinsically linked but not one in the same.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:30, topic:387365”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=483168.msg3541898#msg3541898 date=1300923065]
Is that like sales tax? That is ridiculous! Here I pay 6.5% sales tax, and I think it is too much.
[/quote]redneck

I pay almost 10% :([/quote]

Well, some states, Tennessee for example, have 11% or so sales tax, but no state income tax, so it evens out. Here we have state income tax.

So every year, I have to pay:
Property tax on my house and land
Sales tax on everything I buy
Federal Income tax
State Income tax
(and city tax, if you live in a city)

What should be done, is apply a standard income tax on EVERYONE, like 10-20%, and no other tax at all. Or, my preferred solution, have a sales tax of 10-30% or so, and no other tax at all. Either way would be a fair way to do it.

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:29, topic:387365”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=483168.msg3541847#msg3541847 date=1300920521]
Tell her she will be paying 40% of her salary in tax and then that any good she buys will be taxed at 40% as well. Oh and that is to fund the people who are either too lazy to find a job or don’t declare their income properly.
[/quote]
Wrong. The GST (which is like Britain’s VAT) is 10%, not 40%. Also, you’ll find that Australians do alright as far as taxation goes. We get taxed 0 - 45% of our income, but personal income tax in Britain is actually 0 - 50%.
America is similiar, with about 45% taxation on the highest incomes as well.

New Zealanders do well, with taxation capped at 33% of personal income.
Some European nations (Sweden, Belgium, among others) have personal tax going up to nearly 60%.

I basically know all of this because I was looking for the most profitable place to start a startup - obviously you wouldn’t want to be paying the majority of your money away in taxes if you were to sell.[/quote]

I thought there was a 40% tax on goods that is added on to the GST. I doubt that now though.

Taxation here is terrible. If you have a semi-decent job which contributes to society, 40% of your money goes to the government. Whilst if your are a jobless waste of space and contribute nothing to society, you don’t pay any tax and the government gives you pocket money to spend on drugs.

I am a student and I am not liable for the ‘youth allowance’ scheme yet most of my friends are liable for it even when they are mostly much better off economically than I am.

Lothy I have heard some people talking about the man who has the highest salary in Australia who only paid $25 tax in a year. Is this true? Confirm plz.

Look up debit tax. It’s a great alternative to this communist system.

Frell:

SPREADING THE WEALTH RADEON

Socialism. Is it not?

Read full topic

item.title: Parents moving to australia
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Radeon:

Tell her she will be paying 40% of her salary in tax and then that any good she buys will be taxed at 40% as well. Oh and that is to fund the people who are either too lazy to find a job or don’t declare their income properly.

Wrong. The GST (which is like Britain’s VAT) is 10%, not 40%. Also, you’ll find that Australians do alright as far as taxation goes. We get taxed 0 - 45% of our income, but personal income tax in Britain is actually 0 - 50%.
America is similiar, with about 45% taxation on the highest incomes as well.

New Zealanders do well, with taxation capped at 33% of personal income.
Some European nations (Sweden, Belgium, among others) have personal tax going up to nearly 60%.

I basically know all of this because I was looking for the most profitable place to start a startup - obviously you wouldn’t want to be paying the majority of your money away in taxes if you were to sell.

Read full topic
